snippet: One of the country’s largest recent grass-roots protests shut down traffic in Baghdad on Friday night, and more protests took place Saturday in southern Iraq.
abstract: Temperatures of 120 degrees or more have exacerbated already deep problems with electricity in Iraq, leading to massive grass-roots protest that shut down traffic in Baghdad; protesters blame corruption for power rationing and outages, despite fact that Prime Min Haider al-Abadi has eliminated perk of 24-hour power for air conditioning in offices and homes of government officials.

byline.contributor: Omar Al-Jawoshy and Falih Hassan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: One of the country’s largest recent grass-roots protests shut down traffic in Baghdad on Friday night, and more protests took place Saturday in southern Iraq.

headline.main: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat for Iraqis
headline.print_headline: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat
